choices.C: The Services field does not allow source NAT and destination NAT to be combined in the same policy.
choices.D: The Services field does not allow multiple sources of traffic, to use multiple services, to connect to a single computer.
choices.A: The Services field removes the requirement of creating multiple VIPs for different services.
choices.B: The Services field is used when several VIPs need to be bundled into VIP groups.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
A is correct

FortiGate Security 6.2 Study Guide - Page191 - The Services option has been added to VIP objects. When services and port forward are configured, only a single mapped port can be configured. However, multiple external ports can be mapped to that single internal port.This configuration was made possible to allow for complex scenarios where multiple sources of traffic are using multiple services to connect to a single computer, while requiring a combination of source and destination NAT, and not requiring numerous VIPs to be bundled into VIP groups. VIPs with different services are considered non-overlapping.
A is Correct
It says "If the Services field is configured in a Virtual IP (VIP)". D makes more sense

comments.content:
On the contrary, the Services Field allows a complex scenario where multiple sources 
using multiple services can connect to a single source, so D isn't the answer.

questions.question_text: If the Services field is configured in a Virtual IP (VIP), which of the following statements is true when central NAT is used?

choices.D: One firewall policy in VDOM2 with InterVDOM1 as the source interface and port1 as the destination interface.
choices.B: A static or dynamic route in VDOM1 with the subnet 10.200.1.0/24 as the destination.
choices.C: One firewall policy in VDOM1 with port2 as the source interface and InterVDOM0 as the destination interface.
choices.A: A static or dynamic route in VDOM2 with the subnet 10.0.1.0/24 as the destination.

discussion.content: C & D are chouse two i think is correct
no routing needed, C and D are answer,

comments.content:
routes are required if both VDOMs are in NAT mode (which is not the case here).
VDOM1 is working in transparent mode. meaning that, VDOM2 is directly connected to both Subnets. Therefore, no need for routing

discussion.content: I think A & D, since in the Forti Infra 6.2 says that routes are required to route packets between two VDOMs.
Answer is C&D
C and D are correct.

C & D are correct. No routes need be configured because both networks are directly connected. Also because vdom1 is transparent all that is needed is a firewall policy as the client will have link1 IP as the gateway. vdom2 also needs a firewall policy to allow the traffic to reach destination interface.

C and D are correct... (Question says "choose two")
A is NOT correct cause you need to allow traffic from 10.0.1.10 to 10.200.1.2, so the destination is 10.200.1.0/24 subnet
B is not correct cause the static route must be configured in VDOM2
A and C
A and D.
A & C are correct.

comments.content: sorry I mean A and D.
I Agree , only the fact that VDOM1 is transparent directs on answers A and C.

questions.question_text:
View the exhibit.
//IMG//

VDOM1 is operating in transparent mode VDOM2 is operating in NAT Route mode. There is an inteface VDOM link between both VDOMs. A client workstation with the IP address 10.0.1.10/24 is connected to port2. A web server with the IP address 10.200.1.2/24 is connected to port1.
What is required in the FortiGate configuration to route and allow connections from the client workstation to the web server? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AB
A and B are Correct
It's correct A&B
A and B are correct!
The correct answers are A and B. FortiGate_Security_6.2_Study_Guide-Online (Page 101).

questions.question_text: What criteria does FortiGate use to look for a matching firewall policy to process traffic? (Choose two.)

choices.D: Lowest to highest policy ID number.
choices.A: Services defined in the firewall policy.
choices.C: Highest to lowest priority defined in the firewall policy.
Addicting.Games can be allowed only if the Filter Overrides actions is set to Exempt.
choices.A: Addicting.Games is allowed based on the Application Overrides configuration.
choices.B: Addicting.Games is blocked on the Filter Overrides configuration.
choices.D: Addcting.Games is allowed based on the Categories configuration.

discussion.content:
- FGT Security 7.2 p310
 - The application control profile scans for matches in this order:
 ○ Application and filter overrides: If you have configured any applications overrides or filter overrides, the application control profile considers those first. It looks for a matching override starting at the top of the list, like firewall policies.
 ○ Categories: Finally, the application control profiles applies the action that you've configured for applications in your selected categories.

A is the answer. based on the Scan order. Application and Filter overrides>>Category
Application and Filter overrides follows the same rules as firewall policy. Application override will be considered first. Fortigate_secutity 6.4 study guide Pg438

comments.content:
I take it back. 
It is allowed.
A

questions.question_text: Which of the following static routes are not maintained in the routing table?

comments.content: This is, policy route arent static routes

ISDB is configured as "static route" but will be added to the "policy routes"

I think D is not a correct answer, because the question is referring to "static route configuration". Policy route is not configured as static route (i.e. configured directly from the policy route)
If i have to choose only one i would choose C, because the real name is policy base routes, not policy routes.
It didnt ask for 2 so the answer is D
